question: Who succeeded Brezhnev as Soviet premier?

Kosygin.justification: Alexei Kosygin was a prominent Soviet politician who served as the Chairman of the Council of Ministers, effectively the Soviet premier, from 1964 to 1980. Given his experience and position, it's reasonable to assume he could have succeeded Brezhnev. However, his declining health and eventual replacement by Nikolai Tikhonov might have hindered his chances.

Gromyko.justification: Andrei Gromyko was a veteran Soviet diplomat and politician who served as the Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1957 to 1985. His experience and influence within the Soviet government make him a plausible candidate, but his lack of direct experience in domestic policy might have reduced his chances of succeeding Brezhnev.

Ustinov.justification: Dmitry Ustinov was a Soviet politician and military leader who served as the Minister of Defense from 1976 to 1984. His close relationship with Brezhnev and his position as a key figure in the Soviet military-industrial complex make him a strong candidate. However, his lack of experience in civilian administration might have been a drawback.

Chernenko.justification: Konstantin Chernenko was a Soviet politician who served as the General Secretary of the Communist Party from 1984 to 1985. Although he succeeded Andropov, his rise to power was likely facilitated by his close relationship with Brezhnev, making him a potential candidate to succeed Brezhnev directly.

Tikhonov.justification: Nikolai Tikhonov was a Soviet politician who served as the Chairman of the Council of Ministers from 1980 to 1985. While he did eventually become premier, his relatively late rise to prominence and lack of experience in high-level politics before 1980 reduce his chances of succeeding Brezhnev immediately.

Grechko.justification: Andrei Grechko was a Soviet military leader who served as the Minister of Defense from 1967 to 1976. Although he was a prominent figure in the Soviet military, his lack of experience in civilian administration and his relatively early death in 1976 reduce his chances of succeeding Brezhnev.

Podgorny.justification: Nikolai Podgorny was a Soviet politician who served as the Chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet from 1965 to 1977. Although he held a high-ranking position, his eventual dismissal and replacement by Brezhnev himself suggest that he might not have been a strong candidate to succeed Brezhnev.

Mazurov.justification: Kirill Mazurov was a Soviet politician who served as the First Deputy Chairman of the Council of Ministers from 1965 to 1978. Although he held a prominent position, his lack of experience in high-level leadership roles and his relatively low profile reduce his chances of succeeding Brezhnev.

Polyansky.justification: Dmitry Polyansky was a Soviet politician who served as the First Deputy Chairman of the Council of Ministers from 1962 to 1973. Although he held a high-ranking position, his relatively early retirement and lack of experience in high-level leadership roles after 1973 reduce his chances of succeeding Brezhnev.

Kirilenko.justification: Andrei Kirilenko was a Soviet politician who served as a member of the Politburo from 1962 to 1982. Although he was a prominent figure in the Soviet government, his lack of experience in high-level leadership roles and his relatively low profile reduce his chances of succeeding Brezhnev, but his influence within the Communist Party makes him a plausible candidate nonetheless.
